H0.text: Heat energy is the kind of energy into which most of the incoming electrical energy changes when an electric fan is running.

H1.text: Light energy is the kind of energy that most of the incoming electrical energy changes into when an electric fan is running.

H2.text: Mechanical energy is the type of energy into which most of the incoming electrical energy changes when an electric fan is running.

H3.text: Sound energy is the kind of energy that most of the incoming electrical energy changes into when an electric fan is running.

A4.text: An electric motor is a machine that converts electrical energy into mechanical energy.

A5.text: Losses are mainly due to resistive losses in windings, core losses and mechanical losses in bearings, and aerodynamic losses, particularly where cooling fans are present, also occur.

A6.text: A fan is a powered machine that creates airflow. A fan consists of rotating vanes or blades, generally made of wood, plastic, or metal, which act on the air.
